race.name: 6 Hours of Syllamo
race.tagline: 6-hour Arkansas endurance on Syllamo Trail in Mountain View.

terrain.surface: Mixed singletrack and gravel on Syllamo Trail. 6-hour time-based format with moderate elevation per lap.
features: Moderate elevation per lap (5000 feet total)

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional AR event. 6-hour format and technical terrain are interesting but moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: 6 Hours of Syllamo is a 6-hour endurance event in Mountain View, Arkansas‚ÄîSyllamo Trail with mixed technical terrain. The 6-hour format and technical terrain create an interesting challenge, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it in Tier 3. Mountain View provides moderate access. Spring/fall weather adds variability.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Arkansas endurance event with technical Syllamo Trail terrain. Worth it for Arkansas cyclists seeking a 6-hour challenge. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: 6-hour Arkansas endurance on Syllamo Trail in Mountain View.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Arkansas and want a 6-hour technical endurance event‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're from out of state‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better endurance events: other 6-hour races. For similar regional events: other AR cycling events.

non_negotiables.why: 6-hour format requires sustained endurance and pacing.
Syllamo Trail has technical sections requiring bike handling.

logistics.explanation: Running-focused event organization with field limits of 125 stage entries and 250 total. Blanchard Springs basecamp provides free camping and hot showers. Course flagging exists but riders note "if you're prone to getting lost, you'll get bonus miles" as courses change yearly.

length.explanation: Multiple distance options from 4.17-mile loops up to 50 miles across the Three Days of Syllamo format. The Cotter Bridge Ultra offers timed distances: 6 hours covers 25 miles on 4.17-mile laps. Strict lap timing with DNF for exceeding 60 minutes per loop. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Highly maintained singletrack through rugged, rocky, steep terrain with creek crossings and bluffs. Syllamo and Sylamore trails demand technical skills on densely forested paths. The Cotter Bridge option offers "minimal technical features" on crushed gravel for less skilled riders. More technical than most ‚Äî comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: The 50-mile stage race delivers 7,500 feet of gain averaging 150-170 feet per mile, reaching 200+ feet per mile in sections. Elevation ranges from 300 to 1,400 feet above sea level. Cotter Bridge alternative offers minimal elevation at just 15 feet per mile. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: March conditions hit around 55¬∞F with cloud cover based on historical reports. Creek levels vary dramatically with rainfall, affecting crossing difficulty. June timing for Cotter Bridge avoids winter weather but introduces summer heat exposure. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Maximum elevation of 1,400 feet above sea level creates zero altitude impact. Starting elevation around 300 feet means even sea-level residents need no acclimatization period. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Remote Arkansas wilderness through Sylamore Ranger District and Ozark Highlands trails. Creek soaks at Sylamore Creek provide post-race recovery. Courses change annually, eliminating pre-riding advantages and ensuring fresh exploration of the trail system.

prestige.explanation: AURA newsletter describes Three Days of Syllamo as "daunting" with established trail running reputation. However, no cycling-specific recognition exists as all documented events focus on running disciplines rather than gravel or cycling competition.

race_quality.explanation: Aid stations positioned every 4-9 miles with generous cutoff times: Day 1 allows 10 hours, Day 2 allows 14 hours. Strict timing enforcement on Cotter Bridge with immediate DNF for late laps. Organization appears functional but limited to running events.

experience.explanation: Multi-day basecamp experience at Blanchard Springs with communal meals and evening gatherings. Post-race creek soaking and campfire activities extend the outdoor experience. iRunFar coverage highlights the remote Arkansas wilderness character.

community.explanation: Basecamp format encourages interaction across the three-day format. Blanchard Springs provides central gathering space with shared facilities. Limited field sizes of 125-250 create intimate community atmosphere rather than mass participation events.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 100-200 riders, entry limits keep fields manageable but constrained. No documented elite cyclists or professional-level competition. Running focus means cycling talent depth remains unknown, with all documented participants coming from trail running backgrounds. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Liles describes the cabin setup as "priced well to split 3 ways and everyone gets their own bed to sleep in, clean towels, along with full kitchen and a hot shower." Wilson notes quality trophies with cash prizes for winners. The technical trail system provides substantial challenge across 50 miles of remote Arkansas terrain, delivering solid adventure value for the entry investment.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Mountain View, Arkansas location keeps travel and lodging costs modest. Free basecamp camping reduces accommodation expenses. However, no cycling-specific cost data available as all documented events focus on running gear and preparation needs. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

videos.description:
Looking for the top 10 Mountain Bike Trails in Northwest Arkansas?  Lucky you.. here is the list. https://nwatravelguide.com/top-10-mountain-bike-trails-northwest-arkansas/

Find out more regarding NWA: üëáüëáüëáüëáüëá

‚ù§Ô∏èSubscribe to our channel for the info you want to know about Northwest Arkansas! https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChqko1C1Ks4lg8m9hAHxFgw?sub_confirmation=1

Thankfully, NWA has some of the most scenic and challenging single track trails in the country.  The trails are world-class and so spectacular that two of them won a Bronze and a Silver IMBA designation this past year.  Even though they are among the most competitive in the world, every skill level can still be accommodated. 


Bentonville Bike Trails
Slaughter Pen Hollow Trail is a 30 mile loop trail located near Bentonville, Arkansas and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for mountain biking and is accessible year-round. Slaughter Pen trails are fast and have flow with enough technical stuff to make it hard.


Bella Vista
Trail: Back 40 trail  is a world-class and favorite cross country single track with awesome berms and some great downhills with some tech stuff and a little bit of everything else.

Blowing Springs Trails are fast and have flow with the more technical stuff and better scenery than Slaughter Pen. The trails include caves, waterfalls, springs, and cliff riding and is popular with hikers, mountain bikers, and trail runners year-round. The loop nets about six miles and connects easily to Slaughter Pen for more mileage.

Eureka Springs
Lake Leatherwood trail has over 21 miles of low impact multi-use trails.

Fayetteville
Lake Fayetteville trail has a 5.50 mile loop that is family-friendly and is a good place to get a quick ride includes a hardwood forest, waterfall, wild flowers and is primarily used for mountain biking & trail running and is also accessible year-round.

Mt. Sequoyah trail is a  popular 10-mile natural-surface trail is situated above downtown Fayetteville and winds its way through the forested hillside of Mount Sequoyah. It is considered technical with lots of rocks but the scenery is well worth it.

Mount Kessler trail is a lot like Sequoyah (unique and rocky trail) but a little more technical with some great scenery as well.


 Devil‚Äôs Den State Park has one of the oldest mountain bike trails (Fossil Flats) in the State of Arkansas. The park also offers scenic hiking trails and camping and fishing.


Rogers
Hobbs State Park trail system is really smooth with a lot of climbing.

Railyard Bike Park & Lake Atalanta Trail
Lake Atalanta Trail circles the springfed lake, and takes you through some Ozark forest. The Railyard Bike Park has world-class dirt jumps, wood ramps, 20-foot gaps and even railroad cars. Cyclists of every skill level can enjoy this park.


Honorable Mention:
Lincoln Lake is sometimes referred to as ‚Äúlittle Devils Den‚Äù offers some awesome towering bluffs, hardwood forest, a pine forest, passes by many caves and has great views of the lake.
